item.description:
Hi, Everyone!

Sometimes, we branch out of live theatre to see other types of art in the area. 

This art exhibit at RISD is getting lots of buzz. It's a collection of British art donated by Providence native and major art collector, Richard Brown Baker. Some artists that are particularly interesting: Banksy, the notorious graffiti artist; and Anish Kapoor, who does some really cool things with space distortion. Plus a lot of other notable artists from the U.K.

Free admission

Admission is normally $10 but is FREE the 3rd Thursday of the month from 5 to 9 pm (a.k.a. Gallery Night), so that's when we're going.

There are 2 entrances to the museum. We'll meet in the lobby of the newest wing of the RISD museum on N. Main St. at 6:30 pm. After the exhibit, we'll have dinner and stimulating conversation (well, that depends on you) at Harry's Bar & Burger, just down the street. For non-meat eaters, there are a few vegetarian items on the menu.

No need to buy any tickets in advance (it's FREE), but please RSVP so I can try to make a reservation for dinner. If you can't get to the museum right at 6:30, let me know, and you can catch up with us later.

Parking - there are metered spaces, 2-hour spaces and paid lots along N. Main St. Bring quarters and an eagle eye for empty spaces!

Summary (from the Providence Phoenix)

"Made In the UK: Contemporary Art from the Richard Brown Baker Collection," a survey of post-World War II British art, arrives as British artists are the top of the pops. When British figurative painter Lucian Freud died at age 88 in July, The Washington Post said he was "often considered the greatest living master of the human form." Team Britain also includes Banksy, regarded by many to be the greatest living street artist; Andy Goldsworthy, a preeminent land artist; and Damien Hirst, the sensational self-promoter best known for a 1991 artwork consisting of dead shark floating in a formaldehyde-filled tank that he poetically dubbed The Physical Impossibility of Death In the Mind of Someone Living.

Everything here is from RISD's collection of British art (which the museum trumpets as "uniquely strong in the United States") thanks to Providence native Richard Brown Baker, a major New York art collector who died in 2002 and bequeathed some 170 British works and funding to the museum.
item.how_to_find_us: We'll meet inside the entrance on North Main St.
item.name: Made in the U.K. art exhibit - RISD
